metadata.case_name: Management (Pradeep Lamp Works) v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Strike launched by the workers on the morning of the 27th February, 1964.
Lock-out declared by the Management on February 27, 1964, beginning with February 28, 1964 and ending with March 22, 1964.

On March 20, 1964 the Governor of Bihar referred the following disputes to the Industrial Tribunal: Whether the strike launched by the workers on the morning of the 27th February, 1964, was justified? Whether the lock-out declared by the Management is justified? Whether the workmen are entitled to wages for the period of strike and or lock-out.
Tribunal held that the strike by the workmen on February 27, 1964 was not justified.
Tribunal held that the lock-out declared by the Management on February 27, 1964 was justified but no justification for continuing the lock-out on the following days.
Tribunal decided that the workmen were entitled to wages for the remaining period of the lock-out.

Proceedings of the Tribunal held on September 29, 1966: Parties present; Management represented by Shri Pandey S. Prasad; workmen by advocates; written statement filed late and not accepted; Workers Union adduces evidence; Management examines M.W.1 Trilokinath Rastogi and M.W.2 Shri R.M. Kahattriya; Management prays for adjournment to examine more witnesses, prayer rejected; oral evidence of management closed; Union examines L.W.1 Krishna Thakur; case adjourned to next day.
Appellant made a written application on September 29, 1966 seeking opportunity for producing witnesses named therein, but prayer disallowed.
Trivial instance of slapping a workman which led to a demand by the workmen for an apology from the offending party, leading to the strike and lock-out.
Award dated October 13, 1966 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, Patna in Reference No. 7 of 1964 pronounced on November 10, 1966.

legal_issues.text: Whether the lock-out by the Management was justified after February 27, 1964?
Whether the workmen are entitled to wages for the period of lock-out between February 28, 1964 and March 22, 1964?
Whether the appellant had been deprived of a reasonable opportunity of adducing evidence in support of its case before the Tribunal?

petitioner_arguments.text: The finding of fact that the lock-out was unjustified after February 27, 1964 is not open to challenge, but the order is open to question because the appellant was deprived of a reasonable opportunity of adducing evidence; Tribunal wrongly rejected prayer for adjournment on September 29, 1966 despite giving time to Karamchari Sangh; discretion exercised arbitrarily and contrary to judicial procedure; written application for witnesses disallowed discriminatorily.
Full wages cannot be awarded for the lock-out period as blame is apportionable to both parties; normal practice is to award half wages.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: India General Navigation and Railway Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen (1960 2 S.C.R. 1); India Marine Service Private Ltd. v. Their Workmen (1963 3 S.C.R. 575)

respondent_arguments.text: Parties must be presumed to have been directed to come ready with oral evidence on September 29, 1966; appellant should have produced previous order to rebut presumption; question of adjournment is matter of discretion not assailable under Article 136.

Management adopting dilatory tactics; trivial slapping incident led to demand for apology, strike and lock-out; workmen deprived of wages for one illegal strike day; thereafter willing to work but management continued unjustified lock-out; full wages justified.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant conceded finding of fact on strike not open to challenge.
Order disallowing adjournment prima facie arbitrary and injudicious; more appropriate to adjourn to following day on costs.
Incumbent on Tribunal to apply mind to apportionment of blame between parties and its effect on wages for lock-out after February 28, 1964; order ignoring this infirm and difficult to sustain.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Blame on both parties requires apportionment.

holdings.text: Tribunal's order on continuation of lock-out and wages infirm as it failed to apportion blame between parties.
Tribunal's rejection of adjournment prima facie arbitrary.

precedents_cited.case_name: India General Navigation and Railway Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: When blame attaches to both parties in illegal strike context, divide loss half and half; award half wages.

precedents_cited.case_name: India Marine Service Private Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Where unjustified strike followed by lock-out that becomes unjustified due to duration, apportion blame half and half; award half wages.
Assault on workman not serious enough to justify lock-out continuation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Scope of appeal by special leave; findings of fact generally not challengeable but procedural fairness reviewable.

outcome.summary: Appeal directed against Tribunal award holding lock-out unjustified after Feb 27 and awarding full wages; Court finds Tribunal failed to apportion blame and exercise discretion properly on evidence but text cuts off without final explicit order; indicates infirmity in award.
outcome.relief_granted: Implied criticism suggesting remand consideration for apportionment and evidence.

key_quotes.text: "When the blame attaches to both the parties, we think that they should divide the loss half and half between them."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle from precedent applied to wages apportionment.

key_quotes.text: "In a case where a strike is unjustified and is followed by a lock-out which becomes unjustified a case for apportionment of blame arises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly relevant to facts; supports half wages.

key_quotes.text: "The order of the Tribunal ignoring this important aspect is infirm and is difficult to sustain."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's key finding on wages award error.
